reviewText: I'm old enough to remember the mainstream, televisable "humor" of the 1960s and 70s. Ethnic humor was hugely popular and ubiquitous. Before "All in the Family" debuted in 1971, humor had more than a little of the air of "retread" about it. Jackie Gleason and Lucille Ball (who both peaked in the early 50s) were still all over the tube, as were Gilligan's Island, F Troop and McHales's Navy. This stuff was not funny then, and it is less funny now.By chance, I caught this collection of Dean Martin's "Man of the Week" roasts at my Dad's house. Talk about a ride in the way-back machine -- I was transfixed! Calling a show "*Man* of the Week" should tell all you want to know about the show's social consciousness, but just imagine the situation: a cast of big Hollywood comic names, all well past their prime, dressed in tuxes (and, for the occasional woman, an evening gown), reading material from cue cards written by staff, howling helplessly at the supposed hilarity of their comic genius colleagues. That is what you get with this "Best of" collection. The jokes--all lame, tame and non-topical--are clearly written by the same person or team. Usually, they refer to a standard physical feature or habit of one of the guests. Jack Benny is cheap! Jackie Gleason is fat! Dean Martin is a drunk! Bob Hope is never home long enough to see his family! Johnny Carson (har!) has been married multiple times! The humor is so plastic, the laughs so manufactured, the reactions so excessive that this works only if it was some unbelievable put-on.But it's not.Later in the collection, Martin adds some color to his cast -- Redd Foxx, Mohammed Ali, Tony Orlando, Freddie Prinz. But when the humor is not utterly racist, it is horrific. "And I know about the back of the bus!" riffs Foxx (LOL!) Tony Orlando and Ali are going to open a soap business called "Spic and Shine." (Ha!) Mohammed Ali quips, "I heard of throwing a punch, but never throwing a roast!" (Oh, man!) The laff riot goes on and on. One actor (no idea who) does a long and "hilarious" imitation of an Indian powwow, complete with make-believe Indian dialog and singing - the "HEY! How are you!" variety. By the 1970s, when the series aired, you might think Americans had had enough of mocking a race they had nearly exterminated. And a bit aimed at Foxx about how "his people" used to literally roast people (yuk!) had me shaking my head in disbelief. There was something sad and pathetic about watching so many stars, whose legitimate contributions are legendary, groveling on this show for a few scraps of attention and maybe a bill or two at the end of the night.Strictly from a historical perspective, it is fun to see so many now-deceased stars share the same table -- George Burns, Jack Benny, Milton Berle, Johnny Carson, Dean Martin, Bob Hope, Jimmy Stewart to name a few. And one or two of the bits are funny. Art Carney, one of the only folks who still had comic talent, reprieved some of his "Honeymooners" shtick with Gleason. This, and basic respect to the past talents of the participants, is what saves from being a 1- this review.This is one piece of Americana that should stay firmly locked on a dark shelf in the back room of the Comedy Museum. It is an embarrassment to the great talents who participated, it sends horrible messages about the permissibility of stereotyping ethnic groups and it glamorizes the kind of drop-dead drunkenness that was once thought to be funny. Skip this piece of trash if you possibly can. Let the 1970s, and the 1950s stars who inhabited them, die in peace.

reviewText: Recently thought about seeing those old roasts and found them on amazon, I ordered the celebrity roasts and am not disappointed, it still as funny as when they originally ran on the dean martin show. This video was delivered promptly and was in great condition, works well.
